item.title: Assignment 2
item.description: Write at least 1300 words in response to one of the numbered topics below. Make sure to present arguments clearly. Also remember that a criticism of an argument cannot simply describe a different perspective or support a different conclusion; instead it must argue that there is a problem either with the target argument's logic or with one or more of its premises. Write as if you're addressing someone who is not in the class and does not have a background in philosophy.

item.title: Assignment 1
item.description: Pick a statement that reflects something you believe. This assignment might be slightly easier if it is a statement that not everyone believes, but it will work fine either way. It should be something that you want to think more about, and maybe a statement for which the justification is not obvious. item.title: Interpreting Grades
item.description: This note about grading and interpreting grades just adds some detail to what the course syllabus already says about grading. 4-point scale Grades in this course are assigned and calculated using Hofstra's 4-point scale (described here in the Hofstra Bulletin). Following the Bulletin, the alphabetical grades, including plus (+) and minus (–), have the following 4-point scale values (and vice versa): letter 4pt Student’s academic performance … A 4.
